title: chiarimenti sull'utilizzo della password principale
content:
Salve a tutti, lavoro con win10 e firefox portable edition 141.0, potreste spiegarmi esattamente come funziona la password principale che immetto all'avvio di una sessione di firefox? Io avevo firefox con numerose credenziali gia memorizzate. Successivamente ho deciso per sicurezza di creare una password principale, da quanto avevo capito se questa non viene digitata all'inizio della sessione di firefox tutte le altre credenziali sono protette e non si può accedere ai siti che le richiedono (a meno che uno non faccia una nuova login per ogni sito). Invece ciò che ho notato è che anche se non digito la password principale (e faccio annulla invece di immetterla) posso comunque loggarmi ai vari siti che hanno le credenziali salvate in firefox. Non capisco, non dovrebbe essere impossibile loggarsi a quei siti senza aver immesso all'inizio la password principale? ho fatto qualcosa di sbagliato?

Grazie
creator: giulio.guardati

title: Windows taskbar doesn't unhide when Firefox is maximised by dragging
content:
Current situation: I start Firefox and it starts maximized. When I move the mouse cursor to the lower edge of the screen, the taskbar should unhide but it remains hidden. To correct for this by dragging the window so it resizes (floating window) and then maximaze by pressing the maximize button on top right. Now the task bar unhides as expected.

If I drag the window so it resizes (floating window) and then maximaze by dragging it to the top edge of screen, then the taskbar again wont unhide.

I must do this every time I open a new Firefox window.

I can replicate this whenever I want.
creator: merik1403

title: address bar remembers keyword search
content:
I actively use keywords to search from the address bar, mainly g for google, gs for google scholar and w for wikipedia. Until a recent update (until last week, I think), pressing ctrl + L to go to the address bar would select all the text in the address bar, including the keyword, such that if I had made a google search by typing g and some query, I could immediately do a wikipedia search by typing w and some query.

Now, with an updated firefox (141.0.3, on xubuntu 24.04), the search engine from the previous search remains when I press ctrl + L, so I have to type backspace(s) to remove the search engine keyword, before typing a new keyword.

Is it possible to get the old behaviour back?
creator: tor.nordam

title: Firefox doesn't play sound, even after registering in volume mixer
content:
Hi!

Since I came back from 3 weeks off, it seems Firefox is not able to produce sound. I followed "What to do if Firefox won't play sounds" and "Fix common audio and video issues" but none of them seem to have resolved the issue.

I tested on Twitch, YouTube and mdn web docs for <audio>. None of them work.

  • Volume control : https://i.imgur.com/w12jObX.png (the output device is correct: https://i.imgur.com/hSkMIWS.png)
  • Reload the website : done
  • Allow autoplay of media with sound : https://i.imgur.com/JWN0FYl.png
  • Media Feature Pack : should not be applicable, I'm on Win 10 Home https://i.imgur.com/kjutTM7.png
  • DRM : unrelated (audio on mdn doesn't work either)
  • Clear the cache: done
  • Disable interfering extensions : reseted profiles in about:profiles and during my tests I deleted C:\...\AppData\Roaming\Mozilla after a re-install
  • Firefox settings : done, reseted as part of about:profiles deletion

Chrome, Edge and other applications don't have issues.

What am I missing? Thanks!
creator: funkysayu

title: Constantly Crashing
content:
I've been suffering from crashes constantly for about two weeks or so, maybe more before I started to feel like something was wrong. I've tried everything on the list as far as I can tell.

Firefox is up to date, windows is up to date, my gpu is up to date, and my security is up to date.

I've scanned for viruses and such, nothing.

I've checked for third party modules, nothing.

I've run in trouble shooting mode and it crashed even faster than without.

The only thing I haven't done is checked my ram, and that's only because I feel like if the ram was the issue I'd be having other problems. Maybe that's foolish to think, I'll go back and try that if necessary.

Here's the report: bp-629adab2-23db-49e8-a83a-27d1f0250817
creator: p4r4llelus3r

title: Why is Firefox's Browser History UI still SO AWFUL?
content:
To preface, I'll probably die using Firefox but there are some things that are so annoying that it does. Browsing history being one of them. I swear the browser history UI is stuck in 2003. The way it sorts your browsing history and displays them doesn't make any $!@#ing sense. Chrome's history view is 1000x better and it follows common sense. Chromes will show you the day and time you visited a site in chronological order and it will preserve that. Firefox shows it in a half assed way, it won't tell you the time you visited the site and in some views it will just move that site around in your history when you click on it which is so annoying.

Firefox by default needs to have a nofrills history tab that opens up instead of a sidebar, in that history tab it should display your chronological order of sites you've just visited with the time and date. That should be preserved.

Anyone else feel this pain?

Is there an open Mozilla feedback item about overhauling the history UI? It seems way over due.
creator: anandshivani2025
